review_title: Lots of potential, positive culture, great people, very chaotic
pros:
--The people: I've been with Womply for around a year, and I love the people I work with.
--Work-life balance: from what I've seen, the company sticks to their word and encourages you to "unplug" when you're not at work and take vacation days to recharge. The management I report to does seem to work long/hard but they are under a lot of pressure to produce results and grow, as you can imagine in a startup with 8 years under its belt. If you function best with a strict 8 or 9-hour workday, be sure to talk about that with the recruiter and/or your interviewer to make sure the expectations are understood by all parties, and then hold them to that when you get hired.
--Casual dress code, relaxed atmosphere. I despise formal/stuffy business attire and this is a huge plus for me. (see below for downsides of casual/open office environment). If you are deeply offended by C level management wearing t-shirts/jeans/shorts/hoodies, look elsewhere for employment. You are certainly free to wear whatever formal business attire you wish.
--Huge opportunity/potential for growth/chance to make a real difference. The benefit to small businesses who use the product is real and substantial. The "startup culture" and the resulting chaos (see "cons" below) means that if you're a self-starter and you see something that needs to be done, chances are nobody else is doing it or has seen the need for it, and you can spearhead some really significant initiatives, make a real difference, and get the credit you deserve.
--The product provides real value. The data assets are huge and business owners. The concept is is a winner and has the potential to change the world for local businesses.
--You will get credit/kudos/recognition for the work you do and the difference you make. Management is very open and free with praise and everyone is eager to share or even defer the credit for goals met and key projects completed. Nobody beats their chest and says it's all about me.
--Freeloaders can snack/eat/drink soda for free all day long. Frequent food brought in for the office.
--Company seems to be getting its feet under it and is in position to get it right and grow huge.
--Decent money, good benefits.
cons:
--Chaos. "Startup culture" can mean a lot of things, but here it means "oh crap we never thought of that we better fix it." The last year has been rough, as you can see from the reviews about huge sales staff turnover and people leaving. In my personal view, the people who have been let go were honestly not performing up to expectations or producing significant, measurable results. And naturally you can expect them to be bitter in some cases. But I would also encourage you to take the ultra-negative comments with a grain of salt. Not many people will write a glowing review after being fired. And honestly, if you're not meeting the expectations you were hired to meet, shouldn't you expect repercussions? But yeah, if you crave a drama-free, opportunity-free, worker-bee job where you just punch the clock and do your time, look elsewhere. At Womply you will be challenged, and the challenges are enormous and can feel insurmountable at times.
--The "open plan office" is murder for people who prefer things quiet to maximise their productivity. Seriously whoever came up with this dumb-arse idea needs to be broken on the rack. So if you don't thrive with terrible pop music constantly on in the background and/or if you're distracted by other people's conversations/clicking pens/sociopathic whistling/loud chewing/flatulence/passive-aggressive typing/inane blather/whatever, invest in some quality noise-canceling headphones, or apply elsewhere.
--Working remotely is discouraged. They do allow it but they expect it to be the rare exception, and from what I've seen it's usually when people are sick that they work from home. Management does want people on site whenever possible (and due to the "focus on results" company value and the and "rise and grind" mentality of some people, lots of people come in sick). So if you work best from a home office, look elsewhere or be sure to get whatever WFH arrangement you get them to agree to in writing so there are no surprises.
advice_to_mgmt:
--Reconsider the open office plan
--Continue emphasizing/exemplifying core company values and a healthy work-life balance
--"Have fun" company value needs to actually mean something
--Sales processes that should have been in place 8 years ago need to be in place.
--Dedicate enough people/bandwidth to truly fix problems rather than just applying temporary band-aid solutions.
--Have a longer/foundational view of growing the business. (This is improving)

cons: It's a startup so things move fast, and are a bit chaotic..... but the advantage is that my input is heard and changes are made. You are not some corporate drone...

review_title: Unbiased review; just keepin' it real
pros:
- Met some cool coworkers. I think part of the reason we bonded so well is because we were all so miserable together at work.
- Learned new things, at least in the beginning
cons:
- TL;DR I would not recommend working here unless you absolutely have no other option and can filter out all the negativity that engulfs every aspect of this company.
- Compensation: Salary is well below industry average. Bonus is tied to company target, which means you'll probably get screwed. Equity is a joke. Leadership won't disclose the number of outstanding shares, equity % or valuation because they don't want people to know your options' true worth-- zero. Don't count on annual raises and cost of living adjustments. You're actually taking a pay cut each year because your costs are increasing while your salary stays stagnant.
- Career development: None whatsoever. There is no emphasis or resource spent on training and learning. You are there to do your job, not learn new skills that would make you more valuable elsewhere. Only a few get promoted per year (outside of sales), and even then it's just title and a small salary bump. You will however be taking on extra responsibilities from the constant deluge of coworkers leaving. More work, same pay, no thanks.
- Speaking of turnover: Many quit or get fired within the first year of employment. Hire fast, fire fast mentality. Leadership thinks this is normal and average for the industry. It's even worse and more obvious for VPs and department heads, where execs last an average of 6 months. It doesn't matter if they hire the best of the best-- they will not last long enough for their ideas and leadership to gain any traction. This is definitely the norm (for dysfunctional and failing companies).
- Culture: I've read a lot about toxic workplaces, and this company checks all the boxes. There's always talk about how things will get better, but that's all it is-- talk. Those newly in charge of improving culture and workplace experience eventually leave, starting the cycle all over again. Employee satisfaction surveys show very low engagement. Leadership's solution is to purge unhappy employees, then hire fresh recruits that are unaware of what's happening. The honeymoon period lasts about 2 months before new hires realize how dire the situation is.
- Benefits: Your get the standard medical, vision, dental, 401k without match, junk food and soda. Lunch is provided once a week. Nothing extra.
- Time off / WFH / WLB: Highly dependent on team and manager. Flexible PTO is designed to save on costs, not benefit the employee. If you take less than the standard 3-4 weeks, company wins. If you take more than 3-4 weeks, your vacation is denied. WFH is strongly discouraged but some people seem to do it half the week. Some teams work the typical 9-5 / 40 hours a week, or less, while some managers expect you to be available nights / weekends, at their beck and call. But those managers are just the messengers because the leaders call all the shots.
- Leadership (namely founder and president): They are the smartest and hardest working guys in the room. To their credit, they built a company that employs hundreds. They'd do it all by themselves without anyone else, if they could only clone themselves. Everyone else is just a replaceable cog, a necessary evil, a short term fix. Employees are told what to do, micromanaged, berated for errors, blamed for failures. They're in total denial regarding disgruntled employees, angry customers, and unhappy partners.
- Product: Kind of cool at first, but the core product provides little benefit to most. A small subset will find it useful and worth the cost. But make no mistake-- this is NOT a product-first company. Nobody has any idea how many paying customers actually use the product, and nobody seems to care. Customer engagement is kind of a running joke. An SF-based, big data tech company that sells itself on its trillions of data points and AI- and ML-driven insights doesn't have simple customer engagement data? Over half the org is made up of sales, sales support, marketing, growth. Very few work on the actual product itself. In contrast, there are some very successful companies with a great product and 0 sales. There is no product research, not even simply asking small businesses what they find useful and really need.
- Core values: They're a joke because nobody follows them even though they're posted all over the walls. In fact, they seemingly do the exact opposite of what the core values state. If I were to rewrite them, the main core value would be make money by any means necessary. Second core value would be do the wrong thing until you get caught, then cover it up and deny any knowledge. Third, blame others for anything that goes wrong.
- Ethics: While nothing this company does is outright illegal, their tactics are highly unethical and immoral. They will rarely straight up lie, but they are very careful with word choice. It's meant to mislead and deceive. This can be seen from management's Glassdoor responses to the sales script. They also withhold information, embellish facts and twist data to prove their agenda. They have no issues with charging unknowing, hard-working small businesses while providing zero value. Most "paying" customers were auto-enrolled and don't even know they're paying. These are the same small businesses they claim they're trying to help thrive.
- Glassdoor reviews: The reviews are polarized, an inverted bell curve. People either seem to love it or hate it, not much in between. The truth: new employees are encouraged to leave a review, and many of those are 5 stars because there's not much to complain about in the first week. Many of those reviews read "Pros: free soda, great product, awesome sales managers // Cons: none, but if i have to name one, the traffic sucks". Many of the 1 star reviews are written by very bitter former employees, of which there are many. In addition, there is a concerted effort by management to cover up poor ratings on other review sites too. BTW, none of the bad reviews are written by ex-employees who were fired. They threaten to sue you if you do. If those who were fired had a voice to express themselves without fear of retribution, the average rating would be much worse.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Watch the fyre festival documentary and try to learn something from their mistakes. I see a lot of similarities.
- Instead of covering up negative Glassdoor reviews, fix the root of the problem and make Womply a better place to work. Hey, now there's a novel idea!

- overbilling partners based on false sales data
- deliberately not allowing auto-enrolled merchants to opt out of their “free trial”
- presenting fabricated product use and engagement statistics to current and prospective partners
- lying to employees about executive departures

Unless you have no other options, save yourself some pain and invest elsewhere!

You'll find that the bulk of the "positive" reviews are left by employees currently working there but under 1 year. Hard pass. Get out. Find just about anything else.

review_title: Take all opportunities and run with them!
pros:
Womply truly makes an effort to provide opportunity to anyone who is willing to take it. They hire people from all walks of life and don't adhere to the typical "culture fit" criteria that one hears among many loud Silicon Valley voices. After an 8 year career in finance, no tech firm would hire me because of my lack of experience selling SaaS, however Womply sure did. I took advantage of this opportunity and became the most successful SDR there. They noticed my efforts and offered me the opportunity to hire and train their first class of SDRs at their new location. I was then promoted to an Account Executive role where I ranked 1st or 2nd in the company most of the time.

As an account executive, middle management noticed that I sold a particular feature of the flagship product very well. They then gave me the opportunity to hold a series of seminars teaching the other sales representatives how to sell this particular feature.

Look at me now; I’m the CEO of a successful startup. I sincerely thank Toby and Cory for instilling a culture at Womply that embraces diversity. Had it not been for them, I may not be where I am today.

Much love!
cons: The sales model may have changed since I was employed by the company, but from my experience the primary con is that the sales roles at Womply are not a good fit for everyone. Despite this, they still try to hire people with every type of personality; even if their personality isn't one that screams success and competitiveness.
advice_to_mgmt: If possible, perhaps weed out candidates who you believe do not have the attributes and characteristics of your most successful sales people.

Within two weeks of working there it was clear that that was not the case. Upper management in the Boost division have an Elitist attitude with very little training. review_title: Read these reviews carefully, there are several all saying the same thing
pros: Honestly they have good benefits as soon as you start. Medical, dental etc. Free soda machines and decent amount of snacks
cons:
Oh the irony of leaving a review for a company that manages reviews for other companies.

I know. You’re thinking, “wow $40,000? And literally no experience required? Sign me up!” Not so fast. Do you remember when your mom would tell you “if it’s too good to be true it probably is”? That’s this job. Marc will give you a call shortly after you apply (I’ll explain later). He’ll talk about how some reps are on pace for 6 figures. They might be, but not in Boost. I can’t speak for Core. You’ll think to yourself, wow this sounds like a good opportunity. He’ll talk about the expected growth as Womply is in a start up phase. I don’t know if you could count a business that’s been in business for eight years to be in a start up phase.

You’ll have a group interview and then a private interview. Then they’ll tell you you basically have the job. You might think “that’s weird, that was a little too easy”. It was. It’s because they’re desperate.

You’ll spend a few days with a lady named Sofia. She’s the rah rah person for Womply. She’ll get you fired up and excited about the position. She’s good at her job. The product itself is a good product. It makes sense. You’ll think to yourself “this will be a piece of cake” and “I probably can make $10,000 in commission”. It’s not and you won’t.

You’ll get up to the floor and have your first few calls on the phone. It’ll be weird if you’ve never done it and sure you’ll get used to it. You’ll start to get the hang of things but still won’t know what you’re doing. This is the issue with Womply. There’s literally no training. Do you want to improve your skills and actually become good at this job? Figure it out yourself. Outside of the training from the first week, don’t plan on getting any pointers. I’ve never been a manager before so take this with a grain of salt but how about some actual training in here? Who knows what the managers are doing all day because it’s definitely not developing SDRs. Would it be that hard to have a one hour training like even twice a week for newer people? Meanwhile they keep upping the KPIs (Key Performance Indicators) thinking “if we raise the standard everyone will do it”. News flash 80% (not an exaggeration) of SDRs aren’t even hitting the old KPI so why would you bump it up?

Here’s the best part, the closers or the Account Executives. They get warm leads (someone who is interested) all day, get paid more ($20/hr) and get more commission (usually the first month of whatever they close at) and do less work! Also when numbers are down, SDRs are told to “get to work” and “have a big day”. The biggest issue is the close rate. Only about 10% of transfers (warm leads you send to an AE) end up closing. What happens to the other 90%? They get lost, some genuinely aren’t interested but majority of them are just busy. AE’s have no incentive to continually follow up, why would they when they get a new person on the phone who is interested? A big problem is getting the decision maker on the phone, putting them on hold for a minute because all the AE’s have their headphones off and are hanging out with each other. Sometimes the decision makers are on the fence and let me tell you, putting them on hold for a minute to “talk to your manager” is not helping your odds. Also all the leads are shared. Meaning there’s 10,000 leads in the dialer and it’s first come first served. One of the most frustrating parts is when you call someone who was called earlier this morning because the person who called it first was too lazy to put some notes or disposition it to be call even tomorrow. Simply put this shouldn’t even be an issue and could honestly be solved with a single training. You’re going in blind because your other SDRs are too lazy to actually develop leads and just throw them back into the queue However, if you’re an AE this is a pretty cushy job.

After a few weeks it’ll be clear (they hire 10-12 people a week EVERY WEEK) that you either figure it out yourself (kudos to those 15% people) or they just get on you about getting your numbers up all the time. They don’t provide any structure or training or really any commission ($10K at $6-$10/transfer so 83 transfers in a month which is unheard of two or three might do 50 in a month). This is the most inefficiently run organization I’ve ever seen. Managers don’t actually do anything to help you in your position. If you take this job, understand that you won’t receive any training or really any attention.

Only take this job if you are truly desperate because I believe some income is better than no income. In the meantime continue searching for another job.
advice_to_mgmt: Why is there no training for SDRs? What makes you think that hiring 12 people a week is a good thing (and don't say growth because just as many quit as you hire every week)? What do managers actually do? How does a business that has to hire 12 SDRs a week function?

review_title: Does not get any worse than Womply
pros: The ping pong table that everyone uses to escape the job they all hate
cons:
The hardest part about leaving a review on Womply is knowing which of all the terrible things should you put on here. But let's give it a hack.

There was a previous review on here where someone claimed that Womply tells the new hires to leave a positive glassdoor review upon onboarding. This is ABSOLUTELY true. They responded to that negative review to cover their dishonest practice but I have been with this company for a long time and this happens every hire class. (Which is every two weeks and they still can't keep up with their employee churn.)

So many lies with Womply. For starters let's look at their Glassdoor page. It says Cory Capoccia is their CEO. Lie. It is Toby Scammell (who went to prison for insider trading). The problem was his CEO approval rating was awful because people were exposing him for the CEO he truly is. He once added a "Core Value" of "Embrace Diversity" only to become the biggest offender of the value. He can constantly be heard making fun of the LDS church. He does not care about his employees, as evidence shows with his senior management churn. 8 different senior managers across a variety of functions left after only lasting about 6 months or less.

There has only been one to last longer than 6 months, only because his is the only ego around to rival that of Toby's. He actually has a sign on his door essentially stating, in the most obnoxious way, that his time is more valuable than yours, so don't bother him. He sits in his office all day refusing to interact with anyone and working on either one of two things: his weekly commission plan change or a new sappy LinkedIn post. His LinkedIn profile is his favorite thing about himself. If for some reason he has to come out of his office, he puts in his airpods and hastily walks through the office pretending to be on some important phone call so nobody will say hi to him. Heaven forbid he actually has to talk to one of his employees. He epitomizes the term "good ole boys". The only job security you have with this guy is if you can play a decent round of golf with him, or make obscene jokes about other employees behind their backs.

This company is full of unqualified individuals leading the sales team. One of them who has never had another sales job outside of Womply but thinks he knows everything there is to know about sales and dictates as such. There is no conversation with this guy, outside of yes sir. You cannot collaborate on ideas and if you try, it is seen as insubordination and you could very well be on the outs.

They lie to prospective employees saying they can make up to 200k a year. That could not be any further from the truth. The best salesperson there is on pace for about 85k and he is an anomaly. Most that make it past 3 month (which are very few) only make about 40k.

They don't technically lie to prospective clients but they do deceive them as much as they can. With careful wording they make it seem like they are their credit card processor reaching out in customer service manner, only to turn it into a sales call. This obviously infuriates these business owners. If they do happen to get someone to buy the product, they don't actually buy into the software but into a free trial that Womply hopes they forget about. Nobody actually uses the malfunctional software, they just forget to cancel the trial and get billed for it every month through their processor.

The other deceitful thing they do is what they call "auto-enroll" but then changed to the enrollment team. This was supposed to help with the shady practices's image. They charge customers through the credit card processor for the product without ever getting their permission.

Womply is largely dependent on the partnerships they have with the credit card processors. That relationship is deteriorating rapidly. Womply is inducing churn and upsetting the processor's client base and as a result they have stopped sending them leads. Because of this they went from doing around 150 sales a day to doing about 30.

Do not work for this company. They will lie, deceive and do anything they can to try and get you to come onboard, only to push you out the door three months later. Turn and run from the worst company in the valley.
advice_to_mgmt: They wouldn't take any advice. Advice would be for the board to clear out Toby and Cory and a few more of those senior positions.

 Top reps make 80-100k False, Top reps make 50k no one has made even 80k thus far. 1 person might make 6 figures in 2018 but he will beat everyone by 30-40k. review_title: Hoping for the best, but used to the worst.
pros: Ask anyone who’s left the company, and they will tell you that their peers are the sole reason they’ve stayed as long as they did. During my first 2-3 months at the company, at least 6 people quit. They didn’t get fired, they QUIT. That’s more than the amount of people that quit in a year at my job prior. I don’t care what anyone says, that’s a red flag. It’s sad, but people easily see through the smoke and mirrors soon after they’re hired and quit in less than a year.

When people continue to drop like flies for the same reasons you would think that management would take a look at themselves to see if there is anything they can do differently, but apparently they’re never at fault. That’s what happens when you are considered Employee #X instead of an actual person. You will be taken advantage of, you will be talked down to, and you will always be replaceable. Just ask any member of the SF sales team. And if you’re lucky, they will look for your replacement while you are still employed without giving you so much as a warning to improve.

I hear they have a VP of People now (something that was long overdue), so I can only hope he/she is making positive changes for the sake of future employees and the longevity of the company.

pros:
It's important to note that the experience an hourly employee will have at Womply is very different from the experience a salaried employee will have. Here are my observations:

Hourly:

- Personable and friendly sales managers

Salaried:

- Excitement of working for a Bay Area tech start-up.

cons:

Salaried:

advice_to_mgmt:
Strongly consider the following excerpts from Glassdoor reviews:

"The CEO is push and abrasive. Sends condescending emails and messages and then nice to your face."

"CEO is about as friendly as a honey badger."

My experience with the CEO is that he's extremely brilliant and driven, and is very friendly to employees... when he's talking with them face-to-face. Most communication via e-mail, calls, etc. is uncommonly harsh, demanding, and condescending. Employees are routinely told their work is "insufficient", or that they were asked for a deliverable weeks earlier when nobody but the CEO has any memory of it. Employees quickly become accustomed to rarely being thanked for their hard work or being told they've done a good job.

Condescending, demanding requests may stoke egos, but they are toxic to a company's culture. Such requests quickly lead to employees losing respect for senior management and even poking fun at them when they're not around. As senior managers at the company, you'll have to make a serious decision regarding what's most important to you: your ego or your company's culture.

review_title: Challenging culture; do your homework and make an informed decision.
pros:
I joined because of the wide SaaS product set and large market opportunity. I have worked with SMB SaaS for a while and was looking forward to supporting SMB's across a variety of industries.

Lots of recent leadership hires (all external).
cons:
I turned in my notice on the day of my six month anniversary.

Short version: Unrealistic expectations, poor communication, toxic culture, no evidence of promotions or raises among longer tenured team members, and a generally unpleasant feeling the more I learned about the inner workings made the brief time feel like so much longer.

Long version: My role changed significantly between interview and start date, which I thought odd but accepted as part of a rapidly changing environment. It turned out to be a prolonged and unnecessary ambiguity due to poor communication both between my manager and me and with the company at large... compounded by the fact that when I joined there was no org chart or commonly known team structure. When there were questions that crossed team lines, it was either go all the way to the top or play a guessing game in the middle.

The "honeymoon" phase was totally gone in two weeks and I thought I would be fired in under six - both due largely to poor communication with my manager, the founder. Several (5+) others admitted they felt like they could be fired at any time.

When I brought up cultural issues - basically that at least a few of the stated values were commonly viewed as hollow - I was told that was a surprise... and to focus on specifically assigned tasks, not "drift" into self-guided distractions. This was particularly disconcerting since a large part of our interview conversation was about improving company morale to reduce employee attrition, all in an effort to improve productivity and reduce customer attrition in the long run. That's what I thought I was doing...

In my brief time there, it became obvious that the leadership valued skillsets instead of people. Skillsets, in turn, were treated as interchangeable... leading to unilateral shifts in the org without input from team leads or affected individuals (for example, I found out I no longer reported to the founder from someone else that was not my new manager or in HR), revolving door hire fast/ fire fast practices, and generally ignoring the human element of any equation, whether it related to engineering, marketing, sales or other operations. Raises and promotions seem impossible to come by.

Every leader I saw installed was an outside hire. Hopefully they have enough latitude to enact significant cultural change.
advice_to_mgmt:
Be honest with yourselves about why you are in business and then let that guide how you do business.

Right now it seems like there is a veil of secrecy that has to be maintained around the real why behind the business - nobody seems to know anything outside their immediately assigned tasks, if they will be fired that day, or where the company is even headed in the medium to long term.

pros: Soda, free snacks that is the only good thing
cons:
CHURN and BURN company, if you like people not caring for you and being just another butt in a seat this is the company for you. Sales is hourly pay with crappy computers and equipment.

If you want a job that doesnt pay well or offer in PTO or any care for their emoployees this is the company for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay what a real sales job should pay in Utah for a AE, dont take advantage of Utahs young workforce to pay little and expect results.

pros: Clear, concise core values and accountability to core values helped me see that Womply is a perfect fit for me. The vision of the company attracted me to come and contribute to building the Womply brand.
cons: The hiring process took some time, but the recruiters were good at keeping me in the loop.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to target and hire qualified individuals who are good fits for the company.

pros: Free soda fountain and snacks that are fully stocked. Nice coworkers. Products can be very helpful to those who use them properly.
cons: Company is grossly mismanaged in a toxic environment of inexperience and arrogance. Managers will micromanage you until you get burnt out and prefer to motivate by fear. Company also has a penchant for firing a high rate of employees. CEO is very standoffish and prefers to talk only with other managers.
advice_to_mgmt: Rather than fire employees, try to work with and develop current employees, Company rarely moves up employees and tends to hire outside the company for many positions. Don't promise or dangle promotions to employees to get them to work harder. All executives and upper management need to develop real relationships with employees and develop talent already in the company.

review_title: If you have other options, consider them heavily against Womply
pros:
Some good people, though many of them have left or are leaving.

This is still a good opportunity for certain folks - if you need a break, and no one else will hire you, you can learn a lot here. You will pay a price for your tenure, it is not an easy place to work. When you negotiate, make sure you take long hours, stress, and poor perks/benefits into consideration.
cons:
After you've done your research about the CEO/Founder: his controversial past, what he was convicted for - you can make a judgement call on whether this bothers you or not. More noteworthy is how he reacted to getting caught. He's a former Bain consultant, which is not a historical footnote: he's still very much drinking the Kool-Aid, citing their philosophies and giving material to his managers to read. That's worth taking into consideration if you're in engineering or on the creative side of things. He is obsessed with making employees work long hours, and resents having to pay engineers high salaries.

This is not your typical "techie startup." It's built around a pretty shady industry.

This creates a toxic work environment, with a bully culture: people who are not nice can get promoted and people who care about their jobs and coworkers, demoralized. Many quit, many get fired for random reasons. If your manager can shield you, that means you may be able to do your job successfully... as long as they don't get fed up and leave.

The people who are most successful at Womply are the ones that work hard, keep their heads down and their mouths shut. There is no real office culture to speak of, this is not a fun place to work. You can have fun somewhere else, but there's no infrastructure for it at this company. It is not prioritized or valued. You are a means to an end, and that end is the CEO and stakeholders becoming very rich men.

You get to have a job.

If you have any other options, consider them heavily against Womply.
advice_to_mgmt: Many good people have tried to penetrate this brick wall, but were unsuccessful.

pros: I love the enviroment not a lot of micro-management except when you are not doing your job!Great company to work for. management actually knows how to manage and the teams are always social.
cons: Commission is low if you do not have quality calls

review_title: Exciting company and lots of opportunities
pros: The interview and onboarding process was top-notch and makes new employees feel excited and welcome. The vibe on the sales floor is very high energy and the workforce is clearly bought in to the company's vision.
cons: No real cons at this time. The company is experiencing rapid growth and has to deal with the accompanying growing pains (heavy recruiting, moving work spaces) but seems to be handling them adeptly.

pros: uhh...ping pong table in break room?
cons: Promised commissions for 3 months, given excuse after excuse after excuse why it couldn't be delivered. Ended up dissolving the department and screwing everyone with a $5 demotion after the fact, and guess what, no commissions. Avoid working here.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop hiring and overpaying under-qualified people as lower to mid level management. Learn how to keep your word and take care of your employees.

pros: team moral and floor attitude
cons: instability and lack of direction from owners and management

review_title: Excited to start my new adventure!
pros: The people, who make it a fun environment to be a part of. I worked for a publicly traded company for years, so it's nice to be a part of a new startup again. Because it's a startup, you can challenge the status quo to make it better and you get to be a part of a collaborating team who wants to constantly grow.
cons: I'm not too keen on an open floor concept. I like to get to work and need a better space for increased productivity. As a manager, I've worked in both arenas (floor and cubicles/office areas), and for my position, it's necessary that my role be in a more quiet place (noise canceling headphones may restrict outside noise, however, people constantly walking around in an open environment is also distracting to the eye).
advice_to_mgmt: Please consider this Forbes article: "Why Your Open Office Workspace Doesn't Work"

pros: Provided food and snacks and was flexible on works hours
cons: They don't have the best benefits and the pay is pretty low
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in benefits and try not to micromanage everything

pros: Free soda, sometimes snacks if they don't run out
cons: It's a call center style floor with sub par equipment. Cheap headsets, always breaking and computers run terrible. Employees are quitting constantly because of misleading commission pay. Claw backs are nearly unavoidable due to a product with few unique features, and in some cases an auto enroll sale that depends on people forgetting they are paying for it. Good for an in between job if you need cash, but not as a career. Constantly giving people more work and "better" positions. With no promotion or raise, it isn't better. The longer you work here, the more empty promises are given. Stale management structure. The same people have been managing with almost no changes despite having seen some great talent come through. New management positions aren't a reality because employees won't stick around long enough for another manager to make sense.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop finding ways to limit employee income and advancement. "Opportunity" is a filthy word when you are merely giving a larger workload to someone with no pay raise. Playing favorites with a few people who have been there long term, or top performers until they quit, makes other employees bitter.

review_title: Start up's have ups and downs
pros: Overall the people I met and had the pleasure of working with at Womply Utah were great. I chose to accept a position at a start up company with all the fire and steaming splendor start ups offer. I was one of the first people hired at the Utah office. I can say without hesitation that the gentleman who's job it was to kick off the Utah office is one of the coolest people I've met in a long time. He has an uncanny way of managing and bringing out the positive in people. I was treated with pure class. Womply: I say hat's off for what you're trying to kick off and make into something great. Energy was great initially, and there is a ton of potential with the offering. The solution is great in theory, and this could be a great place to land for a while. Overall I can say it's a real opportunity. Software gets better and better...processes improve, and people, new hires and company culture just has room to get better and better. So if you're in for a ride and can handle ups and downs...then give Womply Utah a shot. I can't be mad about moving on, and overall it was a great experience both the good and not so good.
cons: The splendor of start up life has its ugly side too. You don't grow at the rate Womply Utah has since 8/1/2016 and not make some hiring mistakes along the way, or take risks as well. Some risks work out, others are deal breakers. For example: Culture. For me culture and ethics, and doing the right thing for customers is at the top of the list. Just as it takes more than one "clean healthy meal" to get fit...and at a constant effort...so it is with culture. At my departure...there were lots of changes going on, which is only expected at start ups...some changes didn't fit for me, so I moved on.
advice_to_mgmt: Vetting. Hiring and keeping your word. Are you selling the company to acquisition in three years? Be up front about it. The workforce there on the sales floor is supremely disengaged. Find ways to spark buy in and engagement...you as a core group of key people are amazing. Get the vision across the entire sales floor...and be more transparent about what you're doing.

review_title: Dont waste your time - find something else
pros: Soda machine with all you can drink
cons: Not a good place to make money. Low hourly pay rate and everything you sale will cancel before the 4 month clawback period. You will make your hourly wage and nothing more.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep making your money. CEO is about as friendly as a honey badger.

review_title: Utah Stay Clear - CEO Has no clue
pros: Hired a good group of employees. Health benefits aren't bad but no PTO or holiday pay.
cons: The CEO is push and abrasive. Sends condescending emails and messages and then nice to your face. Makes others do his dirty work. Works the managers 60+ hours a week with the illusion they're doing great things. This company does not care about its employees. Sales executives can't make any money because everything they sell cancels. Customers are a revolving door.
advice_to_mgmt: Quit treating people like crap.

pros:
Great staff
Quick decision makers
Tons of growth potential
cons:
Lots of processes that can seem redundant
Chaos of a new company
advice_to_mgmt: Simplify process and get rid of things the unnecessary

pros: Great people, lots of good vibes and friendly
cons: Constantly adjusting wages and lowering previously promised compensation structure. Lowered base wage and standard of hiring. Letting in people who have already proven that they cannot perform, yet they are kept anyway. Outside hires for positions that they will dangle in front of existing employees like a carrot. The systems and tools in place are constantly down and equipment is subpar. For a tech company, womply has the worst tech just to stay cheap. Cubicles and floor are gross.
advice_to_mgmt: LISTEN TO YOUR EMPLOYEES. Everyone is too afraid to voice opinions because there is a fear of losing their job. Open door policy exists without risk to only "favorites". People are let go more often for office politics. Raise wages and start hiring quality people again. Build a structure and fix what's wrong.

pros: The culture at Womply drives an energetic workforce in a fast-paced start up environment. What you see is what you get: the company communicates what it is looking for in its employees, which is grounded in the core values that are shared from day one in the interview. The team you work with is great and you contribute to the growth of promising company.
cons: It's a technology start up company, so expect a fast-paced environment, the need for flexibility and hard work as the company grows. While this is not necessarily bad, make sure you are up for the challenge.

review_title: What you see is what you get
pros: Everyone, from the recruiters to the CEO, was extremely accommodating and transparent at every phase of the hiring process. The company knows what it wants in its people and culture and doesn't apologize for it, which is refreshing. You are given a solid idea of the tradeoffs of working at Womply, with no attempts to sugercoat or distort things to win you over.
cons: If you don't like the fast-paced dynamic of a growing startup, then Womply is not for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Stay true to the company's values

review_title: Good job for introduction to Saas
pros: Account executive positions are great for learning to sell Saas. Usually a fun environment. Lots of social events to build relationships with coworkers
cons: Changed compensation rates without notifying sales team. Lied about laying off entire sales department in SF.

pros: Growth opportunity, genuine approach from management to grow the business, relaxed environment.
cons: Structural and process inefficiencies due to start-up environment,
advice_to_mgmt: Don't be afraid to branch out and implement best practices from other industries.

review_title: “Decent start up company, horrible management, I would personally avoid and find a more established sales company.”
pros: Not many, maybe the free drinks but getting addicted to redbull and five hour to do your job because it sucked so bad doesn't equal out.
cons: Alot. Management fumbles like you wouldn't believe! No good benefits like retirement or PTO, that was a huge downside. They even ripped us on holiday pay they said they would pay out.
advice_to_mgmt: Work on building the right employees. Have a legitimate career path. Don't go over your best employees and hire outside the company. Also build a decent PTO and retirement plan.

pros: If you keep your head down and work hard, you can definitely surpass any of the sales goals you are faced with at this company. This job requires excellent listening skills and a think on your feet mentality. If you possess those traits, you can use this job as a platform to break into a real sales position after 3-6 months.
cons: CLAWBACK. Learn the term, newbies. It'll change your tune real fast about this company. Make no mistake, this is an hourly paid job. Forget about the lure of commission that typically makes a sales job attractive to those who can hustle. There is a very small chance that even your best client will continue to pay after their free trial, therefore almost all of your commission check is temporary. (See - Womply Loan) However, this is not a concern for the SDR team since they get paid (a few dollars) for each hand off to the AE team no matter what. This leads to low quality of lead gen for the Closers. Experienced sales people will understand this type of frustration. Everyone else -- just take note of how this product is more of a redundant luxury than it is a necessity for small business owners.
advice_to_mgmt: Management advice: Invest more in training their SDR's to properly hunt in order for sales to succeed. Overall, take this job as an entry level way to learn the BASICS of sales. Good luck!

pros: Womply has a solid business model, product and is growing! They recently moved their sales office from San Francisco to Utah so there's a lot of energy on the floor and there is a lot of opportunity to learn and for advancement. Great leaders and a fun environment. Stocked snacks and drinks are always nice.
cons: They don't have some of the same perks and benefits as some of the larger companies, but they've been making improvements in this area. The environment feels like a start up which may turn off some people.
advice_to_mgmt: Improve communication to front line employees so everyone's in the loop

pros: The Womply Cafe IE Breakroom was constantly stocked with free goodies.
cons: They expect you to pull upsales on cold calls and meet quotas following a scripted material. However following this script results in taking too long to meet quotas. Those who do meet them do so via directly disobeying orders, and are rewarded with continued employment. They openly admit that they pre stock each persons call cue and that some of these are most defiantly repeat calls. They admittedly give the people they like ques that are filled with guaranteed upsales and give the trash to the people who arent super social and not that into the bowling team. No joke. Its discriminatory favoritism, giving one person an unfair advantage and another a disadvantage right at the moment of hire.
advice_to_mgmt: I would suggest NOT giving certain "Fun" people advantages in their call cue, and others junk ques so they cant get any sales. Your losing out on alot of really good people who could help you grow and protect your business... Sound familiar guys? In the end the "Fun people are going to make Womply flounder...

pros: Sales team was the best bunch to work with
cons: Sales team upper management was out of touch with reality, consistently setting unrealistic goals. The CEO, Engineering, and Product teams simply don't care what the sales team has to say about feedback about product even from the people who use it. The Ivory tower is sinking and sinking fast.
advice_to_mgmt: listen to what everybody has to say instead of ignoring them. The sales team is bringing in the money for you to develop don't ignore them when they are speaking to potential customers from 8 half hours a day.

pros: I've met some of the most amazing people working at womply. Other than that I can't really so much else.
cons: Management is in the complete dark on any important issues regarding the company. The CEO doesn't care about his employees. No paid time off no holiday or Christmas bonus, force you to take 2 weeks off without pay. Account executives get paid hourly. Don't let them tell you there are commissions. Commissions are borrowed money since the accounts always cancel before their free trial since no one pays for the product. They take your commissions back from your next paycheck. They will criticize your work ethic even if you're doing a great job just to find a reason to fire you. They layed off an entire sales force in san francisco and Washington DC. Womply does questionable sketchy things that I can't disclose... Just look for a company that cares about their employees. Stay away from womply.

pros:
I love the core values - Put Merchants First, Focus on Results, Demand Excellence, Act Like an Owner, Bias For Action, Communicate Candidly, Stay Humble, Have Fun.

High energy environment, company in high growth mode.
cons: If you don't like startups with an intense atmosphere, high energy, and high expectations, this job isn't for you. If you're a pretender and not a producer, this job isn't for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the great work, I love it here, expect to stay a long time!

pros: Love the work Enviroment and leadership. Fridge is always stocked with food water drinks the full nine. Everyone works hard and works together closely to make sure we are all inline with one anothers ideas.
cons: Been sitting here for a coulple of minutes trying to think of something to say. the office isnt the coolest. but we are moving soon to a new place so that will be fixed
advice_to_mgmt: Some of Managments Dad jeans are hard to look at as well as take serious

pros: I come in to work every day knowing what my goals are and how to execute them. I have a team of management behind me that allows me to thrive. Working with womply has been a pleasure so far in my experiences. The pay is pretty high comparatively to other similar positions in the area. I dont feel like I have people looming over me at all times during my work day, and therefor I dont feel micromanaged. They treat you like an normal adult and allow you to work at your own pace so long as it matches with company dials/sales goals.
cons: There is a lot of monotonous work during the day that could be simplified. (IE data entry and web searches) The sales spiffs and incentives arent very big and they are too far and few between but the daily hourly wage somewhat makes up for the lack of cash spiffs and prizes
advice_to_mgmt: Promote from within the company, Hiring from outside talent demoralizes people. It shows that they are only as good as the position they were hired on for. Keep the moral up by showing their is opportunity to grow into different positions.

review_title: Good people great way to get your foot into the tech sector
pros: The people. I still have friends there. No other job has that happened to me.
cons: Could be more money. You must be ready for a certain level of chaos

pros: Fast advancement, fun environment, great management, great pay and benefits, stocked break room at all times.
cons: Some times we run out of sugar free red bulls in the break room, I can't think of any real cons though.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the momentum and advice, so far everything has been outstanding. The competitions and rewards are also appreciated.

review_title: Great company; high performers will love it
pros:
- Womply has a great platform where they partner with credit card processors to provide technology products to SMB businesses. They've signed over 35 partnerships which gives them a wedge into this market and a huge opportunity. When we (product) build something, sales and BD can scale it.

- Great office space in SOMA. Stocked kitchen and a great office manager who puts on awesome events (Giants games, Church of 8 wheels, Casino night, etc).

- A ridiculous amount of payments data... more than I think any other company in the world. If you're a data scientist or engineer who likes to work with large data sets to figure out things that impact real businesses, you'll have a ton of fun here.

- Rock solid reputation in the payments space. The BD team is signing new deals regularly and the these companies look at Womply as a leader.
cons:
- If you are not a direct / candid communicator this is not the place for you. You need to be able to give direct feedback and receive it as well.

- Womply needs to build out it leadership team more. There are a gaps that hold it back from faster growth.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the culture you've worked so hard to build alive and fill the gaps on the leadership team.

pros: Challenging work in an attractive industry.
cons: Often changing and inconsistent measurement of success. Lack of a strong senior management team.
advice_to_mgmt: Build a solid senior management team and stick to the reporting and evaluation structure.

pros: Working at Womply is awesome and really fun! I enjoy the Atmosphere! The management is equipped full of people who care for their employees. In fact, I like working at Womply over every other company that I've worked for so far. In fact, i don't plan to leave anytime soon. After all, there are tons of opportunity within the company and they will continue growing for years to come. They treat their employees like any other good business would! They have really good benefits and healthcare packages. This is not just a job, its a career and a good one at that!
cons: To be honest, the only downside that i can think of is the fact that i have to travel an hour and a half to get to work everyday. Nevertheless, i am willing to make such a drive because they truly are an awesome company! I don't fully understand some of these bad reviews. Just like any good company that I know Womply doesn't hesitate to let you go if you don't perform. Nevertheless, that's the way it should be!
advice_to_mgmt: more donuts!

pros:
Good product that's easier to sell than other small business software
Lots of warm leads
Interesting to call across the country
Love working with the rest of the sales team (especially my team)
Social activities are pretty common, there's food, drinks, etc
Office is nice and we play music all day
They offer health insurance/dental/vision so all the basics are covered
Tampons in bathrooms (much appreciated.. lol)
cons:
Start early/finish early is tough if you don't like getting up
Our schedule is rigid--not the sort of job where you make your own hours
I don't know many people outside sales and have only met execs a couple times
There are some cliques of people who have been here a long time, which is good if you know them but tough for newbies
You have to put up numbers or you won't survive. It's easy but you have to work hard.
Tough to take time off with the commission structure
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to the sales people who have been here longest because we know what the merchants want and how to sell them

pros: This is a great place to work. Great location choice with a laid back call floor experience. Office is new to the area with lots of room for growth and stability. No cold calling warm leads.
cons: None if you come to work on time and do your job.
advice_to_mgmt: None as of right now.

pros: Working at Womply is full of perks. The salary can be good, depending on your position and how hard you work. The days seem to fly by because of how busy everybody is. Free snacks / Friday lunches / Giants tickets (sometimes). People are generally friendly here.
cons: There's a divide between management, engineering, and sales. The sales staff live in their own little bubble, it feels like, and seem to either love or hate their job, depending on how good they are at closing. Overall, these few cons seem to be fizzling out as Womply becomes more mature of a company.
advice_to_mgmt: Vet your sales staff more carefully to reduce turnover. Introduce ways for the sales and engineering teams to work more closely together.

pros: Good Sales training, paired with having experienced veterans around you. Simple product to pitch and the business model is solid. Expanding quickly and all leads given to you. Weekly morning meetings to give you an idea of the direction of the future
cons: hours are normally 7-3:30 which can be a grind if you don't live in the city. However, the early get out allows you to beat BART traffic

review_title: A lot of positive changes made
pros: Changed to higher pay that you can make a great living off of. Great new set up where you are set up to succeed and increase your pay. Your pay is determined by your effort. At the end of the day, it's up to you how much in commission you want to make. Great environment and a lot of social people. If you want a chance to get experience in accounting and sales, come here.
cons: Can get repetitive going over same website for business owners.

pros: Awesome place, good people lots of little perks
cons: Pay is just not enough to live on
advice_to_mgmt: Pay more

pros: This is my first time doing sales and it turns out I'm pretty good at it. I've learned a lot working here and like the other people I work with. I work 40 hrs a week and overtime is rare/discouraged. Selling to small business is tough but I like talking to many owners each day.
cons:
Training was short and so I learned a lot on the job. I was lucky to get a good team lead. Others haven't had as much help from people around them and they've struggled.
Compensation is tough for San Francisco. I make enough money but have to work hard for it and show up every day at work. The attendance policy is tough. We get benefits now but I wish we got bigger commissions when we sign big multis.
It's a structured program, which makes it hard to move up super quickly.
advice_to_mgmt:
More opportunities to move up even not to team lead would be good.
Get the current sales reps involved in hiring and training because we know what's up.

review_title: Great place to learn with great people!
pros: Fantastic teammates. I loved working with everyone at Womply day in and day out. It was truly an honor to be around such intelligent people. The cultures and values are also very clearly spelled out and you are held accountable for them. Not all startups know how to get this right.
cons: Unless you're senior leadership (VP and above) you have little say/insight into the depths of the business. Everything is on a 'need to know' basis (aka not very transparent). Work/life balance was also challenging. Do not expect to have a 9-5 schedule if you are a salaried employee.

pros: I can't recommend this company.
cons: Poor sense of company culture. High turn over, hostile work environment.

Cutting Edge technology

too much money concerned

pros: Thorough interviews coupled with a fast decision making process. PDX and SF offices are connected well through technology fostering collaboration. Teams are very responsive and help you come up to speed quickly.
cons: Tenure is too short to assess any cons.

pros: Working with a small Team, had good lengthy training, there was strong coffee
cons:
Gender spread not even
Sugar Free Redbulls
advice_to_mgmt: Get to know future goals of employees

pros: Fast interview decision making, great on-boarding, lots of responsibility, company has great potential if the execution works
cons: Not as many perks as other companies, 401k doesn't start until 3 months after you start, no company match, pay is ... ok

pros: Culture starts at the top and the CEO was found guilty of several felonies and spent time in jail. The office is fun, employees are nice and there is a nice basketball hoop to relieve stress during the day. Fully stocked snack fridge is a nice perk.
cons: Not an ethical place to work and they fire about 75% of the people they hire to avoid paying commissions. Do not think that you will make the amount of money they tell you that you can make. Also, the way they sell the product is unethical and sleezy.
advice_to_mgmt: The Board should start making changes at the top and hire more ethical management.

pros: Fun office & atmosphere. Cool people on sales team so it keeps you happy for a bit.
cons: Sucky job. Sales team is the bottom of the barrel. No benefits. Minimum wage pay. If they focused more on making the sales team happy and giving them a LIVING WAGE they would have less turn around.
advice_to_mgmt: Starting wage should be at least $15 first 30 days and once you get the promotion to AE 2, increase pay. Getting a promotion with no increase is stupid.

pros: Sales team co workers are the coolest. Everyone is nice. They have company picnics.
cons: The sales team is poorly compensated. They also have a lot to do as far as the sales script. Some of the managers have micromanaging tendencies (ie will monitor you to make sure your working ) and do not like when you collaborate too much.
advice_to_mgmt: Compensated the sales team better and listen to their feedback regarding customers. It's healthy for sales people to vent to each other during work when it comes to frustrating calls. As long as we hit numbers...why do u have to walk around and monitor people??

pros: start up company, open to ideas, flexible hours, always food in the kitchen, great location, product idea is good and the coworkers are friendly.
cons: It's a start up company. Their product idea is great, but it's hard to sella product that isn't finished and rarely works right. The training for the newcomers is horrible. there aren't any benefits.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to the sales team and try to keep them a little happy. In the beginning when I worked there, it was great and then they hired a lot of new people with bad training and that nearly lost a lot of partnerships.

pros: The company is growing really fast, has great potential, and a great culture. I definitely felt the energy and excitement throughout the interview process which really attracted me to it. There's an emphasis on career development, diversity, and culture, which is hard to find at almost any company. Smart people and great team. Definitely have a foundation for success.
cons: It's a start-up so there are some growing pains involved. A lot of the processes are still being figured out and need to be optimized. Some long hours if you're not used to it but it's interesting work so not that bad.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to keep your employees excited and retain top talent. There's a lot of stuff to be done but try to make sure everyone is operating as efficiently as possible. Keep it up!

pros:

review_title: Great Place to Start Sales Career.
pros:
Womply is an exciting start up environment, with many opportunities for those who are motivated and able to handle the changing climate of working at a start up.

For anyone who is starting, or continuing their career in sales, should apply. The training program is up tempo, which is great because it allows sales reps to get onto the phones sooner and start collecting commission.

We have social events with the entire company every month, and happy hours for meeting sales goals. The office also provides catered lunch on Fridays (always good, and I am picky) and the kitchen is stocked with plenty of snacks and drinks.

The most appealing part of working at Womply for me is it is a growing company and there is room for advancement if you work hard and show you can handle the responsibility, and the leadership is level headed and easy to work with.
cons:
Being a sales rep at Womply is a phone job so if you are not comfortable on the phone it may be challenging, but I have seen many sales reps struggle at first, but soon figure it out with the right amount of coaching and effort.

Sales is a competitive environment so being able to handle light competition is a must.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue the companies focus on bringing in talented great people to work with.

pros: Location near Giants Ballpark and Caltrain. 7-3PM shift, work stays at work. Free lunch Fridays. Good filler job if you need money for the time being.
cons:
Despite anything the Womply website says about the Account Executive role, it is actually quite different. Sales team are CONTRACTORS. Not actual employees of Womply. You will be hired in to an hourly position. There is NO payroll. Income is paid PRE-TAX. No benefits. No health/dental/401k. No Equity. No Sick days. No anything! Meanwhile, everyone else in the entire company DOES get all the above mentioned benefits. The sales team is excluded. Isn't it supposed to be the other way around? The sales team is very separated from the rest of the company in a lot of ways. IF YOU DIDN'T GRADUATE FROM A TOP TIER SCHOOL, THEN YOU WILL GET NO RESPECT FROM ANYONE OUTSIDE OF THE SALES TEAM.
A lot of transparency issues with OTE earnings that they disclose. I know a few of the Senior Account Executives making no where near the $90k OTE that was stated in the offer, even while outperforming the entire sales team! No opportunity for advancement, no opportunity for transferring to other positions.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat the sales team more like part of the "family" rather than some random people you don't know. Just because we didn't graduate from Stanford, UCLA, USC, etc., doesn't mean that we don't possess the skills necessary to get the job done. The sales team should be offered equal benefits to everyone in the company, no reason that should be different. Fix the pay structure.

pros: I'ts good starter job for a new salesperson to get some real world experience in Tech. Reasonable compensation for an entry level position. Overall culture is festive.
cons: Limited upward and lateral mobility.

pros: There are plenty of snacks such as mixed nuts, cereals, candy bars, gum, mints. If you need caffeine to start or drain your day, they offer tons of energy drinks in the fridge such as RedBull, and 5 Hour Energy drinks.

The training room is a tiny room (5x7'), and they stuff 10 people in that room. I was sweating and grasping for air. There were times where the training manager would give us breaks to leave the room because everyone was about to pass out, and there were times where he couldn't stand being in the room himself and trained us outside in the patio where it was cold and windy. Horrible working conditions.

Womply's office is in a residential condominium. They occupy 2 loft units with no more than 900 sqft. This concerns me as there are many staffs (50-70) cramming their cubicles together. These units are meant for 1-2 people occupancy;not 50.

i don't recommend this company to anyone due to the fact that they hire and fire weekly, and minimal training (2days), then be expected to be terminated by the third day. What is worse on top of that is they fire you in front of everyone since there is no privacy at all except for the restrooms, which are literally right next to working cubicles and kitchen.

Lastly, Not many staff had worked there more than a year. Huge turn over including upper management. You can look them up on Google.
advice_to_mgmt: I hope the CEO of Womply,Toby Scammell won't repeat another felony. Everyone deserves a second chance and I hope he runs Womply accordingly with the law, which I doubt it since I've found many flaws.

Because of the fast rate of growth there's no such thing as boredom as things are always changing keeping you on your feet. The culture is a very supportive one.
